cluster_relations.rel_desc: Superficial communication on social media prioritizes quantity over quality.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is systematically given higher priority or preference than the object, for example in terms of attention, time, or importance.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Online relationships are said to be prioritized over face-to-face interaction.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is systematically given higher priority or preference than the object, for example in terms of attention, time, or importance.
cluster_relations.subject_class_group: Social Media and Online Social Interaction
cluster_relations.object_class_group: Social Media and Online Social Interaction

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: when relying heavily on social media

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject actively gives higher priority, attention, or value to the object relative to alternatives.
args.justification: In this instance, 'superficial communication on social media prioritizes quantity over quality' means the communication practice (subject) gives higher priority to a specific aspect (object: quantity over quality). The current canonical predicate 'is_prioritized_over' with a subject-as-recipient-of-priority semantics does not match; instead, the subject is the agent that prioritizes. Updating to 'prioritizes' aligns directionality and meaning. Both this and similar edges form a prioritization_relation and fit better under a broad PREFERENCE group than AGENCY.

This relation correctly uses 'is_prioritized_over' where the subject (online relationships) is given higher priority than the object (face-to-face interaction). Its existing canonical predicate and description are appropriate, but the broad class group 'AGENCY' is less precise than 'PREFERENCE' for prioritization and comparative preference relations. Aligning the rel_cls_group with that of similar prioritization relations improves schema coherence.
